title.narrative: WHO- Strengthening health systems (UHC, MHPSS, AMR, CXB)
WHO- Strengthening health systems (UHC, MHPSS, AMR, CXB)

description.narrative:
Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is a global health and development threat. It requires urgent multisectoral action in order to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). WHO has declared that AMR is one of the top 10 global public health threats facing humanity. The cost of AMR to the economy is significant. In addition to death and disability, prolonged illness results in longer hospital stays, the need for more expensive medicines and financial challenges for those impacted. AMR is increasing over the years in Bangladesh owing to its poor healthcare standards, along with the misuse and overuse of antimicrobials, which poses a regional and a global threat.
Currently, nearly 890,000 Rohingya refugees escaping persecution in Myanmar reside in the world’s largest refugee camps in Cox’s Bazar As the Rohingya refugee emergency is now largely considered a protracted crisis, there is a need to adapt an integrated multi-sectoral approach to address key public health issues for both the refugees and the host population. The need to find integrated approaches to addressing health issues for both host and refugee populations is always very vital for coexistence between Rohingya and host communities.
The contribution proposes to deliver 4 outcomes and cross-sector and cross-community approach to fullfill the goals. WHO is a strategic partner with close relationship with Government of Bangladesh.

Antimikrobiell resistens (AMR) är ett globalt hälso- och utvecklingshot. Det krävs brådskande sektorsövergripande åtgärder för att uppnå målen för hållbar utveckling. WHO har förklarat att AMR är ett av de 10 största globala hoten mot folkhälsan som mänskligheten står inför.Kostnaden för AMR för ekonomin är betydande. Förutom dödsfall och funktionshinder resulterar det i långvarig sjukdom och längre sjukhusvistelser, behov av dyrare läkemedel och ekonomiska utmaningar för de drabbade. AMR har ökat under årens lopp i Bangladesh på grund av dåliga hälso- och sjukvårdsstandarder, tillsammans med missbruk och överanvändning av antimikrobiella medel, vilket utgör ett regionalt och ett globalt hot.
För närvarande bor nästan 890 000 rohingyaflyktingar som flyr från förföljelse i Myanmar i världens största flyktingläger i Cox's Bazar. Eftersom flyktingkrisen i Rohingya nu till stor del betraktas som en utdragen kris finns det ett behov av att anpassa en integrerad sektorsövergripande strategi för att ta itu med viktiga folkhälsofrågor för både flyktingar och värdbefolkning. Behovet av att hitta integrerade strategier för att ta itu med hälsofrågor för både värd- och flyktingbefolkningen är alltid mycket viktigt för samexistens mellan rohingyafolket och värdsamhällena. I insatsen föreslås fyra resultat och sektorsövergripande strategi för att uppnå målen fullt ut. WHO är en strategisk partner med nära förbindelser med Bangladeshs regering.

Through the project, Sweden is actively supporting ongoing efforts in improving the Bangladesh health care system which will ultimately benefit the poor and the vulnerable. The proposed contribution is directly aligned with the current strategy for Swedens development cooperation with Bangladesh 2021-2025, especially the support area 4 - Strengthen the capacity to provide good quality healthcare.
The project consists of four different health areas: Universal Health Care (UHC), Mental Health and Psychosocial Support (MHPSS), Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) and upholding health services quality in Coxs Bazar. The four health interventions have been identified not only as important in Sweden's Bangladesh strategy 2021-2025 but the interventions are aligned with WHO's Country Cooperation Strategy (CCS), the Global and Regional Priorities of WHO, and the United Nations Development Cooperation Framework (UNSDP) 2022-2026 for Bangladesh.
The project specifically aims to accelerate Bangladesh progress towards achieving UHC through strengthening the country's health financing functions where currently the health care out-of-pocket expenditure is 71%. MHPSS will be supported by education and awareness campaigns, to combat stigma and to ameliorate misconceptions. The project will improve MHPSS information enabling a correct the health seeking behavior and improve the access to MHPSS treatment. Currently in Bangladesh 18.7% of the adult population and 12.6% of children in the country are suffering from mental disorders and there one psychiatric nurse and psychologist for every 300,000 people in Bangladesh and only one psychiatrist for every 650,000 citizens. From a One Health approach the project will aim at support strengthening the Government of Bangladesh AMR surveillance capabilities, improve access to appropriate antimicrobials, ensuring rational use of antimicrobials through improving awareness and enforcing regulations and legislations. As the Rohingya refugee emergency is now largely considered a protracted crisis, there is a need to adapt an integrated multi-sectoral approach to address key public health issues for both the refugees and the host population and to uphold health services quality in Coxs Bazar. The project will aim at improving equitable access to and utilization of quality lifesaving and comprehensive primary and secondary health services for all crisis-affected populations which includes infection prevention timely response to all communicable diseases with outbreak potential, including COVID-19, and preparation for and response to other health emergencies including monsoon and cyclone.
WHO has been chosen as a partner for this project since they are the leading normative actor in the field of health. They have a long-standing relationship with the Government of Bangladesh to whom they have been providing technical assistance to strengthen the country's health system since 1972. WHO has been assessed to have the capacity on a country level to support the suggested interventions. WHO role in this project will be to develop health policies, evidence-based standard guidelines and protocols, capacity enhancement of the health professionals and service providers, strengthening knowledge base and research, monitoring country's health situation, and improve of service delivery and overall strengthening of the health systems.

tag.narrative: 10.3 - Ensure equal opportunity and reduce inequalities of outcome, including by eliminating discriminatory laws, policies and practices and promoting appropriate legislation, policies and action in this regard.

10.3 - Säkerställa lika möjligheter och minska förekomsten av ojämlika utfall, bland annat genom att avskaffa diskriminerande lagstiftning, politik och praxis och främja lagstiftning, politik och åtgärder av lämpligt slag i detta hänseende.
3.4 - By 2030, reduce by one third premature mortality from non-communicable diseases through prevention and treatment and promote mental health and well-being.
3.4 - Till 2030 genom förebyggande insatser och behandling minska det antal människor som dör i förtid av icke smittsamma sjukdomar med en tredjedel samt främja psykisk hälsa och välbefinnande.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

3.8 - Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

3.8 - Åstadkomma allmän hälso- och sjukvård för alla, som även skyddar mot ekonomisk risk, tillgång till grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård av god kvalitet liksom tillgång till säkra, effektiva och ekonomiskt överkomliga grundläggande läkemedel och vaccin av god kvalitet.
3.9 - By 2030, substantially reduce the number of deaths and illnesses from hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination.
3.9 - Till 2030 väsentligt minska antalet döds- och sjukdomsfall till följd av skadliga kemikalier samt föroreningar och kontaminering av luft, vatten och mark.
5.3 - Avskaffa alla skadliga sedvänjor, såsom barnäktenskap, tidiga äktenskap och tvångsäktenskap samt kvinnlig könsstympning.
5.3 - Eliminate all harmful practices, such as child, early and forced marriage and female genital mutilation.

5.6 - Ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health and reproductive rights as agreed in accordance with the Programme of Action of the International Conference on Population and Development and the Beijing Platform for Action and the outcome documents of their review conferences.

5.6 - Säkerställa allmän tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och reproduktiva rättigheter i enlighet med överenskommelserna i handlingsprogrammet från den internationella konferensen om befolkning och utveckling, Pekingplattformen samt slutdokumenten från respektive översynskonferenser.
